name: Tom
comment info:
I am a father of four adult sons the youngest of whom is 21.  All of them have some level of disdain for the world as they find my generation has left it for them to deal with (can't blame them). All of them grew up in parallel with the ever more ubiquitous presence of tech and social media. 

Based on this very small sample size, I wonder if teens and young adults give any thought to how much their views and opinions are influenced by corporate behemoths who have been using AI for some time with the express intent of drawing them every more deeply in a facsimile of the world that is not real and sometimes dangerous. 

What generation might realize the influence of corporate behemoths that are behind these platforms and reject them outright? 

For users of all ages, when will we stop being lab rats for these companies that monetize our eyeballs with no regard to the negative impacts on society?

Have there been any studies on the degree to which kids would say they are more influenced by their social media platforms or some social media "influencer" than they are their parents? I can't imagine being a parent today trying to instill values to my children.

When will Facebook go out of business given the younger generations are not using it? Can't wait for that!

name: Khayden
comment info: Teenagers use social media platforms as a means of communication, self-expression, entertainment, and staying updated with current trends. They connect with friends, share personal experiences, engage with content creators, and join online communities. The benefits of life online for teenagers include increased connectivity with others, access to a vast amount of information, opportunities for self-expression and creativity, and the potential for finding support and community. However, there are also risks associated with life online, such as cyberbullying, privacy concerns, negative impact on mental health, addiction, exposure to online predators, and the distortion of reality through idealized portrayals. It is crucial for teenagers to be aware of these risks, practice responsible digital behavior, and engage in open communication with trusted adults to ensure a positive and safe online experience.

comment info:
I notice that different social media platforms exhibit diverse usage patterns among teens. YouTube and TikTok have higher percentages of teens using them almost constantly or several times a day compared to Snapchat, Instagram, and Facebook. comment info:
I notice first the YouTube is the platform most used by teenagers, which is completely expected because it has both the most content and longer form content that can be more engaging and serve a much larger catalogue of audiences. The opposite here is TikTok and Snapchat which generally have much shorter content and yet both are close to YouTube in terms of constant use. This suggests to me that there may be a crossover between the two groups who use all three platforms for the same shorter content, while YouTube has a broader appeal that TikTok does not.

I wonder how this could be further broken down by age groups, as I'd put good money on the few Facebook users being much older than the average TikTok or even Instagram user. I'd also want to know the reason why each person or demographic prefers their platform, as speculation can only get you so far.

In terms of myself and my community/family I can say I notice a difference in the type of content me and family consume on a daily basis. My brother, who is several years younger than me enjoys a lot of the same topics but watches them in much shorter forms, while my mother watches much different things than I do but in similar length.

A good title would be "The Online Fight for Attention" or something along those lines.

The influence of the internet and minimal social reactions during a person's childhood seems to accelerate the process in which they mature. It is clear that growing up in a digitally connected environment has an impact on a child's childhood and their life in later years. The overwhelming amount of information we encounter in our interconnected world also contributes the accelerated process of maturation that most children who spend excessive time on they internet experience.

I have a younger sister who- in comparison to me, is more in touch with the internet than I was when I was her age. name: Avani SL
comment info:
What do I notice?

Facebook is by far the least-used social media site among teens. Even though TikTok is the most recent app, it is in second place across all five apps. Even though fewer people have Snapchat than Instagram, the people who do have it spend more of their time on it (15% use it almost constantly vs 10% with Instagram). Almost every teenager uses YouTube, which makes sense because it has many applications, like education, long-form entertainment, and short-form entertainment.

What do I wonder?

What does "almost constantly" mean? Does that mean you are using the app every waking hour of your day? Since this was a voluntary survey, how much voluntary response/non-response bias is there? I wonder what the teens who use Facebook use it for? (I know some people who advertise their babysitting/tutoring so parents can see it and don't use it for socializing necessarily.) 

How does this affect my community?

It is clear that many teens spend a large amount of their free time behind a screen, which has been proven to be detrimental to mental health. I also spend a lot of time watching YouTube and on Instagram, so it is interesting to see how many people my age spend even more time online than I do. I think in some ways social media can be a beneficial use of your time, so I think that we as teenagers need to be more aware of when we are just wasting time versus if we are using our time wisely.

Title:

"Screenagers by the Numbers"

name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows how often teens say they use each platform. It shows 5 apps in order from least to most used. I noticed Youtube is the most used app. 19% of teens use it almost constantly and 41% several times a day. There's a significant amount of people who use it about once a day or less often. It can be concluded that most teens use Youtube daily. Sometimes schools assign Youtube videos for educational purposes. I use Youtube a few times a week for school. TikTok is mostly either used a lot or not at all. This is  because 9% of teens use it once a day and only 9% of teens use ti less often. This shows the addictive nature of TikTok as most teens either use it all of the time or not at all. The same concept applies to Snapchat. As a Snapchat user, I can say that you feel pressured to respond to friends’ snaps which makes you want to check your Snap right away when you get a notification. With Instagram, slightly more teens said that they used it once a day or less often. However, most people still either use Instagram a lot or not at all. Recently, Instagram has become more addictive as it has adopted Instagram reels which are a similar concept to TikTok. Finally, the majority of people do not use Facebook. I feel like this is pretty common because Facebook is a more adult-dominant app. Overall, this is relevant to me because this survey proves just how addictive social media can be and therefore implies the negative effects it will have on our brains. 
“App Adicttions”

name: Moderator Corey
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “Is Social Media the New Addiction?” by Justin of Eagle Crest High School in Aurora, Colo., "The Shocking Usage Statistics Behind Today's Social Media Platforms" by Imran of Valley Stream North High School in Franklin Square, N.Y., “Screenagers: How Teens Today Spend Their Time on Social Media” by Luke of McCall High School in Idaho, “Social Media Obsession: Which Platform Reigns Supreme Amongst Teens” by Santiago of Perth Amboy High School in N.J., “Social Media and the Battle for Teens' Attention” by Ms. Lasky’s AP Language at Middleton High School in Wis. and "Is YouTube the New Facebook?" by Sylvia of Pewaukee High School in Wis.

It is interesting how many commenters were surprised that YouTube and not TikTok was in first place!

Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article that includes these graphs.  Also in the Reveal are a summary of the topic, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graphs.

The next graph will be released by Friday, December 8 and live-moderated on Wednesday, December 13.  The topic – Santa’s wages.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who regularly uses only two of these platforms – guess which ones, and Corey Andreasen from The Hague, The Netherlands, who just wants it to stop raining!

name: Jenely
comment info:
P2

For every platform studied, except for YouTube, more teens reported that they don't use the platform more than any other description. For every platform studied, except Facebook, more teens reported using the platform several times a day rather than constantly, about once a day, or less often. YouTube is the most used platform studied and Facebook is the least used platform studied because only 5% of teens do not use YouTube and 67% of teens do not use Facebook. An equal or greater amount of teens reported using EVERY platform studied about once a day or less often in comparison to almost constantly.

Given this, why do most people describe teens as constantly using social media when teens do not report the same? 

This graph is closely related to how I use social media and the ways I see other people my age at school use social media. Most of my day is at school or sleeping. That only leaves so much time for personal obligations, keeping up with friends and family, the gym, reading, or watching television, plus social media. I mostly use YouTube for long periods once a day and only ~3 more platforms for several minutes several times a day.

"How Do Teens Really Use The Most Popular Social Media Platforms?"

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph illustrates the results of a survey conducted by the Pew Research Center asking how often teenagers (13 to 17) use social media throughout the day. The results show that the majority of teenagers who participated use various platforms at least once a day. While only a low percentage responded that they use these social media platforms constantly, most respondents still report having active accounts. 95% of respondents use YouTube, 77% use TikTok, 59% use Snapchat, and 62% use Instagram. I was quite surprised when I noticed that only 16% of respondents reported constantly using TikTok. I wonder if these results are accurate or if these respondents have succumbed to zombie scrolling and are unaware of how much they use social media. I would respond by saying that I am not a constant social media user. But, according to my Apple screen time report, I used social media for around a total of 30 hours last week. In my community, I see how addicted teenagers around me are to social media. In school, students will step out of class to use the restroom but bring their phones to answer snap chats, DMS, or even just watch a few TikToks before heading back to class. I feel that a lot of people are oblivious to the amount of time they spend on social media throughout the day because it has the effect of engulfing a person causing them to lose a sense of time. 

“Double Tap, Like, and Subscribe: How Much Time Do Teenagers Spend on Social Media?”

HI, @Ms.Lasky's AP Lang Block 4 --

Welcome AP Lang Block 4.  Great headline.

You say “YouTube has such a low amount of people who never use it.”  How do we know how many people use each of these platforms and at each level?  

Since there is a number, we want to say “a low number of people.”  The word “amount” is used for nouns that do not have quantitative values, for example fun and sand (if not measured).   “The amount of fun the group had was  increased because of the enormous amount of sand that was put in the playground.”)

name: Caleb P, Tyler Z
comment info:
'Social Media is Taking Over Teens' Minds. How did this happen?'

We noticed:
From April 14th to May 4th, 2022, a survey took place for teenagers asking how often they use social media platforms. When the results came back, YouTube had many teenagers using it over other platforms. It had the highest percentage who used it constantly, several times a day, once a day, or least often. The next most popular platform was TikTok, a newer platform in the US since 2018, and it is still rising in popularity. Other popular apps like Snapchat and Instagram didn't have nearly the same numbers as YouTube in each category, but Facebook was the one that fell short the most with 67% of teens not using it.

Our wonder:
What makes these apps much more familiar among teenagers than apps like Facebook and Twitter, which are also fairly popular?

Our relation:
As teenagers, we might use some of the apps in this list and know what it's like to use them all day or throughout the day.
Teenagers might know better than adults about why these apps are so entertaining, considering we use them so much.
